qas.question: How much did  philanthropic foundations donate between 1925 and 1940?

What was the goal of the behavioral research?

answers.text: President James R. Angell and psychobiologist Robert M. Yerkes

qas.question: What animals sexual behavior did Yerkes study?

plausible_answers.text: President James R. Angell and psychobiologist Robert M. Yerkes

qas.question: Who were the behavioral students in charge of the research?
What animals eating behavior did Yerkes study?

context: Between 1925 and 1940, philanthropic foundations, especially ones connected with the Rockefellers, contributed <a0_0><b5_0>about $7 million<b5_0/><a0_0/> to support the Yale Institute of Human Relations and the affiliated Yerkes Laboratories of Primate Biology. The money went toward <a1_0><b6_0>behavioral science research<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which was supported by foundation officers who aimed to "<a2_0><b7_0>improve mankind<b7_0/><a2_0/>" under an informal, loosely defined human engineering effort. The behavioral scientists at Yale, led by <a3_0><b8_0>President James R. Angell and psychobiologist Robert M. Yerkes<b8_0/><a3_0/>, tapped into foundation largesse by crafting research programs aimed to investigate, then suggest, ways to control, sexual and social behavior. For example, Yerkes analyzed <a4_0><b9_0>chimpanzee<b9_0/><a4_0/> sexual behavior in hopes of illuminating the evolutionary underpinnings of human development and providing information that could ameliorate dysfunction. Ultimately, the behavioral-science results disappointed foundation officers, who shifted their human-engineering funds toward biological sciences.
